item.title:
EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT IN ‚ÄòFINAL STAGES‚Äô OF TALKS WITH CHINA TO REMOVE SANCTIONS - SCMP
The European Parliament is in the ‚Äúfinal stages‚Äù of discussions with Beijing about removing sanctions on its members, smoothing the way for normalised relations with the bloc, according to a spokesperson for the lawmaking body.
‚ÄúDiscussions with the Chinese authorities are continuing and in their final stages,‚Äù the spokesperson said. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.description:
EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT IN ‚ÄòFINAL STAGES‚Äô OF TALKS WITH CHINA TO REMOVE SANCTIONS - SCMP

The European Parliament is in the ‚Äúfinal stages‚Äù of discussions with Beijing about removing sanctions on its members, smoothing the way for normalised relations with the bloc, according to a spokesperson for the lawmaking body.

‚ÄúDiscussions with the Chinese authorities are continuing and in their final stages,‚Äù the spokesperson said.

item.title:
Global trade outlook is deteriorating:
The World Trade Organization expects world merchandise trade to fall -0.2% in 2025, down from +2.7% growth expected at the beginning of the year.
This would follow the +2.9% growth recorded in 2024.
North American trade is set to be hit the hardest, while Asia and Europe will continue to see modest growth.
The WTO also highlights that if the US imposes higher reciprocal tariffs after a 90-day pause, global merchandise trade could drop by -1.5% this year.
For 2026, the WTO forecasts +2.5% growth, down from the previously expected +2.9%.
Global trade is experiencing a historic slowdown. (From TKL)
item.description:
Global trade outlook is deteriorating:

The World Trade Organization expects world merchandise trade to fall -0.2% in 2025, down from +2.7% growth expected at the beginning of the year.

This would follow the +2.9% growth recorded in 2024.

North American trade is set to be hit the hardest, while Asia and Europe will continue to see modest growth.

The WTO also highlights that if the US imposes higher reciprocal tariffs after a 90-day pause, global merchandise trade could drop by -1.5% this year.

For 2026, the WTO forecasts +2.5% growth, down from the previously expected +2.9%.

Global trade is experiencing a historic slowdown.

item.title:
OPTIONS TRADERS POSITIONED FOR MORE WILD STOCK SWINGS
Investors are bracing for more stock market volatility ahead. Options traders are betting on a move of 1% or more, higher or lower, in the S&P 500 for every session through at least May 23, according to a Monday note from Citigroup strategists. Those moves are expected to be higher on days of economic importance: Options are pricing in a swing of 1.8% in the benchmark index when the April jobs report is released, and a move of 1.7% the day of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's post-meeting press conference in May. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.description:
OPTIONS TRADERS POSITIONED FOR MORE WILD STOCK SWINGS

Investors are bracing for more stock market volatility ahead.
Options traders are betting on a move of 1% or more, higher or lower, in the S&P 500 for every session through at least May 23, according to a Monday note from Citigroup strategists.
Those moves are expected to be higher on days of economic importance: Options are pricing in a swing of 1.8% in the benchmark index when the April jobs report is released, and a move of 1.7% the day of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's post-meeting press conference in May.

item.title:
GOLDMAN SACHS LOWERS 1Q GDP ESTIMATE
Goldman Sachs economists now think that the economy grew at a 0.1% annualized pace in the three months through March, down from 0.4% previously. New home sales grew by more than expected last month, but the construction deflator declined by less than Goldman expected, denting the read-through to inflation-adjusted growth. The first official estimate of 1Q GDP from the Commerce Department lands April 30. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.description:
GOLDMAN SACHS LOWERS 1Q GDP ESTIMATE

Goldman Sachs economists now think that the economy grew at a 0.1% annualized pace in the three months through March, down from 0.4% previously. New home sales grew by more than expected last month, but the construction deflator declined by less than Goldman expected, denting the read-through to inflation-adjusted growth. The first official estimate of 1Q GDP from the Commerce Department lands April 30.

item.title:
TRADE, MIGRATION CONCERNS DENT U.S. TOURISM: JPMORGAN
Anti-U.S. sentiment over trade policy and fears of the immigration crackdown overreaching are already hurting tourism from overseas. After an adjustment for calendar timing, Easter travel to the U.S. is looking about 10% worse than last year's level, JPMorgan economist Michael Feroli writes. As a rough estimate, a 10% decline in foreign travel would subtract about 0.1% from GDP in 2025, Feroli concludes. The hit, of course, would be especially apparent in the hotels and restaurants sector, although foreigners are also important customers for educational institutions. In the past, when anti-U.S. sentiment has driven declines in tourism, such as at the start of the 2003 Iraq war, the tourism weakness has been sharp but short-lived. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.description:
TRADE, MIGRATION CONCERNS DENT U.S. TOURISM: JPMORGAN

Anti-U.S. sentiment over trade policy and fears of the immigration crackdown overreaching are already hurting tourism from overseas. After an adjustment for calendar timing, Easter travel to the U.S. is looking about 10% worse than last year's level, JPMorgan economist Michael Feroli writes. As a rough estimate, a 10% decline in foreign travel would subtract about 0.1% from GDP in 2025, Feroli concludes. The hit, of course, would be especially apparent in the hotels and restaurants sector, although foreigners are also important customers for educational institutions. In the past, when anti-U.S. sentiment has driven declines in tourism, such as at the start of the 2003 Iraq war, the tourism weakness has been sharp but short-lived.

More conflicting headlines are likely coming next. (From TKL)

item.title:
Over the last 24 hours:
1. Trump says tariffs on China won‚Äôt be as high as 145% and ‚Äúwill come down substantially"
2. Bessent says "de-escalation with China" is coming
3. WSJ reports that tariffs on China are set to drop to 50%-65%
4. Bessent says America "first does not mean America alone"
5. Bessent declines to comment on WSJ report in point #3
6. Bessent clarifies Trump is not offering a unilateral decrease in tariffs on China
7. Bessent says US-China trade deal will take 2 to 3 years
The market's rollercoaster ride continues. (From TKL)
item.description:
Over the last 24 hours:

1. Trump says tariffs on China won‚Äôt be as high as 145% and ‚Äúwill come down substantially"

2. Bessent says "de-escalation with China" is coming

3. WSJ reports that tariffs on China are set to drop to 50%-65%

4. Bessent says America "first does not mean America alone"

5. Bessent declines to comment on WSJ report in point #3

6. Bessent clarifies Trump is not offering a unilateral decrease in tariffs on China

7. Bessent says US-China trade deal will take 2 to 3 years

The market's rollercoaster ride continues.

item.title:
Here we go again:
Bessent now saying that President Trump has not offered to take down US tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.
The ball is in China's court and Bessent just said it will take 2-3 years to reach a deal.
How does China respond now? (From TKL)
item.description:

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at http://www.reventure.app under a premium plan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at reventure.app under a premium plan.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.
But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.
Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.

But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.

Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.
In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.
Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.

In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.

Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).
The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.
Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years). (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).

The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.

Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years).

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.
However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.

However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.
Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.
Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.
The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.

Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.

Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.

The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.
But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.
For instance, take a look at Manhattan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.

But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.

For instance, take a look at Manhattan.

item.title:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.
Manhattan - 25% undervalued Bronx - 22% DC - 18% New Orelans - 11% San Francisco- 11% Queens - 5% Brooklyn - 4% Chicago - 3% Boston - 2%
All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.
Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.

Manhattan - 25% undervalued
Bronx - 22%
DC - 18%
New Orelans - 11%
San Francisco- 11%
Queens - 5%
Brooklyn - 4%
Chicago - 3%
Boston - 2%

All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.

Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades.

Tariffs are expected to come down from 145% to 50%-65%, per WSJ. (From TKL)
item.description:
Gold is extending losses to -4% on the day as a reduction of U.S. tariffs on China appears to be imminent.

Tariffs are expected to come down from 145% to 50%-65%, per WSJ.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 7) Access the data for Manhattan real estate at http://www.reventure.app, including our overvaluation rates and price forecasts by ZIP code.
You can access both under a premium plan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
7) Access the data for Manhattan real estate at reventure.app, including our overvaluation rates and price forecasts by ZIP code.

You can access both under a premium plan.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 6) No one else in the housing market is really talking about Manhattan.
But I think it could be poised for a big rebound soon.
The market is the cheapest it's been in decades relative to income and rent.
Suggesting a turnaround could be in the offering. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
6) No one else in the housing market is really talking about Manhattan.

But I think it could be poised for a big rebound soon.

The market is the cheapest it's been in decades relative to income and rent.

Suggesting a turnaround could be in the offering.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 5) But you can see that today, Manhattan's "fair value" relative to income has now surpassed its actual value.
Creating an undervalued market. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
5) But you can see that today, Manhattan's "fair value" relative to income has now surpassed its actual value.

Creating an undervalued market.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Today's nominal price in Manhattan is about the same as it was in 2014.
And barely above where it was in 2006.
Evidence that this housing market has been on the struggle bus for a while. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
4) Today's nominal price in Manhattan is about the same as it was in 2014.

And barely above where it was in 2006.

Evidence that this housing market has been on the struggle bus for a while.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) The reason is that home values actually corrected in Manhattan by around 20% from the peak in mid-2022.
Moreover, Manhattan's housing market was also struggling prior to the pandemic.
So in terms of relative affordability, it has gained significantly. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
3) The reason is that home values actually corrected in Manhattan by around 20% from the peak in mid-2022.

Moreover, Manhattan's housing market was also struggling prior to the pandemic.

So in terms of relative affordability, it has gained significantly.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 2) But New York has and always will be expensive.
The question is: how is it priced compared to its long-term norms?
And unquestionably, New York is the cheapest it's been to buy in decades. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
2) But New York has and always will be expensive.

The question is: how is it priced compared to its long-term norms?

And unquestionably, New York is the cheapest it's been to buy in decades.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) Of course, Manhattan is still very expensive.
It's the 8th most expensive county in America, and the only one located outside California.
Typical home/condo value of $1.1 million. With associated mortgage payment of $7,500/month to buy. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
1) Of course, Manhattan is still very expensive.

It's the 8th most expensive county in America, and the only one located outside California.

Typical home/condo value of $1.1 million. With associated mortgage payment of $7,500/month to buy.

item.title:
Typical home (condo/co-op) value in Manhattan today is $1.1 million.
Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.
The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.
Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description:
Typical home (condo/co-op) value in Manhattan today is $1.1 million.

Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.

The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.

Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now.

item.description:

‚Äî¬†@LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."

‚Äî¬†Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession.

item.description:

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic). (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.description: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic).

item.title:
$TSM TSMC Q1 FY25:
‚Ä¢ Revenue +35% Y/Y $25.5B. ‚Ä¢ Gross margin 59% (+6pp Y/Y). ‚Ä¢ Operating margin 49% (+6pp Y/Y). ‚Ä¢ Capex $10.1B (vs. $11.2B in Q4 FY24). ‚Ä¢ EPADR $2.12 ($0.06 beat).
3nm & 5nm were 22% & 36% of revenue. (From App Economy Insights)

item.title:
Despite another round of solid corporate earnings, stocks stepped back early Tuesday following two straight higher sessions. Investors kept an eye on China after Bloomberg reported that Beijing told airlines not to accept any Boeing deliveries or U.S. aircraft gear. Treasury #yields also ticked higher, muting earnings-related enthusiasm as investors remain focused on Treasuries and the #dollar after both suffered tariff-related head colds recently.
üì∞ Read the latest Schwab Market Update: https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/stock-market-update-open
üé•Watch Monday's Big Picture Panel on Market On Close ‚§µÔ∏è (From SchwabR)

item.title:
RT by @SchwabResearch: The ECB will likely cut rates this week by 25bp to 2.25% and remain on course to cut again in June.
As with many other economies apart from the US ‚Äì which is risking a tariff inflation shock on itself ‚Äì trade wars appear disinflationary at a time when Eurozone services inflation is finally turning lower.
The PMI points to continued 2% target inflation in Europe over the coming 6 months, by comparison its pointing closer to 4% in the US. (From SchwabR)
item.description:
The ECB will likely cut rates this week by 25bp to 2.25% and remain on course to cut again in June.

As with many other economies apart from the US ‚Äì which is risking a tariff inflation shock on itself ‚Äì trade wars appear disinflationary at a time when Eurozone services inflation is finally turning lower.

The PMI points to continued 2% target inflation in Europe over the coming 6 months, by comparison its pointing closer to 4% in the US.
